titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Citizens for Traditional Values
Records, 1984-2000
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Elizabeth Konzak

did.abstract: The Citizens for Traditional Values record group documents four separate but interrelated organizations having many of the same members and sharing a strategy aimed at uniting conservative Christians on behalf of similarly-minded candidates for office. These organizations were The Freedom Council (1985-1987), the Michigan Committee for Freedom (1986-1992), the MCFF offshoot organization Celebrate Life (1989-1992), and the Citizens for Traditional Values (1991-present). The record group contains a variety of documentary materials such as office files, correspondence, budgets, reports, fundraising information, draft materials, and news clippings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The materials were donated by Citizens for Traditional Values, James S. Muffett, Executive Director (donor no. 8955) in September 2002.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Citizens for Traditional Values Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Freedom Council (FC -1985-1987) was an organization of devoted Christians actively working "to defend, restore and preserve religious freedom in the US." Pat Robertson, a pro-family conservative Christian, owner of the Christian Broadcasting Network and host of the 700 Club television program, founded the national organization of the Freedom Council. Local Freedom Council chapters worked to get Christians nominated and elected to state and local office, and to lobby legislators on issues of key interest. The FC also strove to fill precinct delegate positions, which would have a primary role in selecting candidates for the state legislature and for state Republican Party leadership positions. The FC was tied closely to Robertson's candidacy for president. When that faltered, the Freedom Council also folded although its overall mission to support Christian candidates and issues was continued through the Michigan Committee For Freedom (MFCC) which had many of the same membership as The Freedom Council.

The Michigan Committee For Freedom (MFCC) was founded in 1986 by David Walters, who had previously worked for the FC. The MFCC was founded to continue the values of the Freedom Council, supporting Christian candidates in state politics, particularly supplying valuable information to precinct delegate candidates on how to win elections in their areas. After the August 1986 election, over 40% of the elected Republican precinct delegates considered themselves part of the MCFF. Prospective presidential candidate Pat Robertson mirrored the values of the MCFF and had the support of many of the candidates. The MCFF and Pat Robertson's potential campaign organization were often viewed interchangeably as the two organizations had many of the same goals and supporters. In February 1987, Robertson won the Michigan Republican Presidential nomination due to the work of the MCFF delegates. Soon after the election, Americans for Robertson (1987-1988) was formed on a national level to assist Robertson with his campaign. After Robertson failed to win the national nomination, the MCFF continued their work to elect moral Christians to public office.

In 1990, the MCFF created an offshoot organization called Celebrate Life. Celebrate Life was an organization created from within the MCFF with the help of longtime staff member Maxine Elwell, dedicated to the right to life movement and the limitation or reversal of abortion legislation. The Celebrate Life had a project in three phases; the first created and printed a newspaper insert that appeared in newspapers all over Michigan. The second and third phases of the Celebrate Life project continued to seek support for the advancement of pro-life issues and advocate for support of adoption and the repeal of abortion legislation.

Since 1991, Citizens for Traditional Values (http://www.geocities.com/ctvweb/) has taken over the political activity of the MCFF. The Citizens for Traditional Values continues to promote conservative Christian political candidates for all levels of government, produces voter's guides, and lobbies for moral issues in the legislature.

scopecontent.p: The record group contains materials from The Michigan Freedom Council (MFC -1985-1987), the Michigan Committee for Freedom (MCFF -- 1986-1992), the MCFF offshoot organization Celebrate Life (1989-1992), and the Council for Traditional Values (1991-present), conservative Christian political activist groups working in Michigan. The records contains a variety of documentary materials such as office files, correspondence, budgets, reports, fundraising information, draft materials, and news clippings to give a well-rounded view of the conservative Christian political scene in Michigan.

The record group begins with a small series of Background Information (1986-1992) that includes organizational materials, brochures, and general information on the Freedom Council and the Michigan Committee for freedom. Of particular note is the oral history interview made with James Muffett describing the delegate selection process leading to the 1987 Michigan Republican presidential candidate nomination for Pat Robertson.

did.unittitle: Statement of Purpose and Goals circa 1991

scopecontent.p: The Freedom Council (1985-1987) series contains three subseries. The Organization subseries includes the report "Plan for Michigan" and additional organizational documents. "Involvement" includes materials on Michigan's precinct delegate nomination process as well as poll results. "Staff and Committees" consists of information on the staff and executive committee. The organization set the groundwork for the delegate selection procedures and the conservative Christian network in the state.

did.unittitle: Legal restrictions on Political Activity undated
Republican Party Rules for Delegate selection 1986-1988
Freedom Council Report by Wm. McPhail, (cassette) 1985
Soliciting Members for the Pennsylvania Freedom Council 1985

Executive Board and Staff Lists undated
Personnel Files (includes James Muffett, John and Michelle Miller, Bob Baldwin) 1985-1986

scopecontent.p: Michigan Committee for Freedom (1986-1992) contains ten subseries. "Organizational Files" (1986-1992) include materials on the organization, its structure, goals, mission, and history. The "Board of Directors Files" (1986-1992) consist of membership lists, meeting minutes, reports, and budgets. "Correspondence" (1986-1991) contains both ingoing and outgoing messages. Correspondence from John and Michelle Miller give some detail about the transition from MFC to MCFF. "Fundraising" (1985-1991) consists of donor correspondence, donor information, and fundraising events. "Financial Records" (1986-1991) include budgets, spreadsheets, and reports. "Chapter Records" (1987-1990) include materials from the district organizations of the MCFF.

The "Convention and Delegates" (1985-1990) subseries consists of rules and procedures for convention attendance, convention strategy files, delegate recruitment and training, the delegate election process, write-in campaigns, polls and results of elections. The materials describe the part delegate selection plays in the Michigan Republican Party and strategies used when electing delegates. The "Voters Guide" materials (1990-1992) include candidate questionnaires, press releases, and distribution information. "Visual Materials" (ca. 1988) consists of videos by Marlene Elwell and Pat Robertson on behalf of the campaign of Pat Robertson. The "News Clippings" (1987-1989) subseries contains clippings from Michigan newspapers about the Michigan Republican delegate process, Pat Robertson's election, and the MCFF role in the win.

scopecontent.p: Celebrate Life (1989-1992) contains materials from the Celebrate Life Organization, divided into six subseries. "Background" (1989-1990) includes correspondence and a certificate of assumed name so MCFF could work under the name of Celebrate Life. "Team 1000" (1989-1990) was the volunteer team who helped fundraise and coordinate the Celebrate Life project. "Phase I" (1989-1990) included the creation of newspaper inserts distributed across the state promoting a pro-life viewpoint. "Phase II" (1989-1990) includes fundraising correspondence, cooperation with other area groups, and a Rally held in 1990. "Research" (1989-1990) includes research on aspects of abortion and abortion issues used to support the project. "Phase III" (1990-1991) materials consist of fundraising correspondence, news releases, and budgets.

did.unittitle: Phase I and II Budgets/ Charts 1990

scopecontent.p: Citizens for Traditional Values is a small series containing donor and supporter correspondence, and news clippings about the organization in the early 1990's. Newsletters and brochures include information about the organization after 1998.
